reviewText: Ten beyond darkness. I've set up the first episode of 'Touching Evil 1 - The Lost Boys' - in my player. I'll probably watch the opening credits by eleven pm to see who Inspector Dave Creegan is. I've left one city - Twin Peaks - waking up somewhere in England for something that I've already decided has to be the next step beyond where I was yesterday. I'm sure that this series has something to do with my life or I wouldn't have been brought to it?'Touching Evil 1's lead character - Dave Creegan? I like him. A man of dark currents who's personnal life is a complete mess; but, he manages to function professionally in his job as crime investigator.Well? Sometimes things happen that cross into his personnal life that take his professional life on a side road that might be inappropriate. But. That makes his vulnerabilities a unigue defense when he steps into that darkness of depraved souls who lurk in places outside humanity / compassion / human soul!-Touching Evil is very methotical / slow moving / observant / voyeuristic-You get to be in another man's controversy / contridiction / confusion / resolution / reflection I've only gotten thru episodes 1 and 2 of session oneThe Lost Boys - Creegan tracking down the killer of childrenTo Death and Back - Mercy Killings of Terminally Ill patients / revelations of his own death Intrigued / caught up in soul stealing mysterys of another man's life! - can't wait to get to- episode 3 tomorrow night -' 'What Amathus Wants 'This is a compelling series that won't let you sleep untilthe final chapter
summary: In The Caress of Touching Evil

reviewText: Without doubt the Touching Evil series is, along with Prime Suspect, Wire in the Blood (also with Robson), one of the finest mysteries ever developed for television. Once again British television leaves its Stateside counterpart in the dust when it comes to creating a well-reasoned, educated yet infinitely watchable "who-done-it?"Robson Green's Creegan has a intensity that is deeply affecting and eminently watchable. Just shy of being over-the-edge, Creegan is instantly likeable yet worrisome; like an old friend whom one is justifiably concerned about. Yet he's not so "out there" that we find it difficult to identify with him. Quite the opposite.Nicola Walker is his perfect partner, D.I. Taylor. Like the best entertainment, Touching Evil isn't a one man show and while the major burden may fall to Robson, he is surrounded with a rich and varied supporting ensemble with a genuinely stand out performance from Shuan Dingwell as D.C. Rivers.I'm glad to see Season 1 finally making it to DVD! Dare I wish for "Touching Evil IV?"p.

reviewText: I'm a big fan of Robson Green and the WIRE IN THE BLOOD series. I heard about TOUCHING EVIL and had to get this series. It predates WIRE IN THE BLOOD but is very similar in many ways.In TOUCHING EVIL, Robson stars as Detective Inspector Dave Creegan with the OSC - the Organized and Serial Crime Unit. As with WIRE IN THE BLOOD, he is working with the main detective of the unit again played by a woman. Nicola Walker is Detective Inspector Susan Taylor. Most of the crimes the investigate involve a demented serial killer. In TOUCHING EVIL, we get to delve more closely into the personal lives of the detectives and how working with serial murders and violent crimes affects their emotional psyche and family life. TOUCHING BLOOD is much more character and story driven than WIRE IN THE BLOOD but equally gruesome in the graphic depiction of murder and mayhem.In each season, there are only two or three episodes that run about 1 hour 40 minutes each. I like the fact that in each series, one story and a few characters will spill across into the next episodes. There may be a new crime to investigate but a previous story still continues. In the typical American TV detective show, everything is clearly wrapped up in each episode, but in TOUCHING EVIL, a story continues in some form.I'm not giving anything away but saying the killer never turns out to be the most likely suspect. The detectives take liberties with searches without warrants that seem highly unlikely or legal. Much like Dr. Tony Hill, Dave Greegan is able to get into the mind of the criminal. He comes to understand the murder's motives. When there is a suspect, he quickly realizes why that person can't be the killer.  Piece by piece the story falls into place. Rarely do they arrive just in time to save the last victim, as is always the case in American shows. This British series takes a different path and that makes it all the more interesting and compelling.The acting is superb. The various characters are intriguing. A highlight in Series 3 is Andy Serkis (famous as Gollum from Peter Jackson's LORD OF THE RINGS TRILOGY) starring as a "Bereavement Counsellor". Dave Creegan has much more personal trauma in his life than WIRE IN THE BLOOD'S Tony Hill. Creegan has flaws and has made mistakes. His intentions are noble but sometimes his actions fall short.TOUCHING EVIL is a fascinating and intriguing detective series. The big disappointment is the series only has a total of 8 episodes. The show was worthy of so many more.
summary: A Totally addictive and Engrossing Detective Series

reviewText: Someone once described John LeCarré's novels as stories of the pretty bad standing guard against the truly awful.  That's a good blurb for Touching Evil.  Hard-bitten cops make war on Britain's most depraved, yet their story has a through-line of corruption and casual brutality warning us that even our heroes are soaked in sin and struggling to stand on their own.Detective Dave Creegan (Robson Green) is dragged back to the Organized and Serial Crimes Unit after extended medical leave.  A gunshot to the head has left him a loose cannon, but the OSC needs his genius in their work as Britain's last ditch law enforcers when the usual routes fall short.  His colleagues fear him as much as the criminals, and his relationship with his ex-wife is up in the air.  But he gets the job done, sometimes in spite of the rules.The writing and the performances are what make this series.  Actors give it their all in tense, multi-layered stories; even walk-on roles have the intensity of heat lightning.  There is precious little violence, most of which happens off-screen, but the characters assault each other with the intensity of their personalities.  Hallway conversations can have the bone-jarring power of a drunken fistfight.Atmospherics can sometimes be hard on the eyes.  The show is very set-bound, and often half-lit and hazy in a way I think is meant to feel creepy.  But the flicker of fluorescent lights, the pall of cigarette smoke, and the muted colors conspire to make me want to Windex the screen.  The show's visual design is best when the characters get out of the set and stare, blinking and dumbfounded, at a harshly sunlit world.The third and final episode leaves something to be desired.  Written when the internet was new and threatening, it features a cyber-killer, but it shows little familiarity with regular technology; I suspect it was meant to be hip and topical, but comes across as merely weird.  Couple that with Diana Rigg's pre-episode narration, which was added for the US broadcast and contains spoilers, and the series ends on its weakest note.But the strong content in the middle, as Creegan starts to reveal his secrets and the corruption of the OSC rears its ugly head, are enough to offset this soft ending.  This is a show for audiences who want the intensity of American crime drama in a character-driven British series.  Gut-wrenching and unrelenting, this wily thriller will leave you gripping your chair with tension and fear.

reviewText: I rarely watch American TV anymore because of the chance to see crime drama at it's best like the "Touching Evil" series.  I have epals that I share my favs with and visa-versa.  The "Touching Evil" series was recommended by an epal because of it's intelligent drama.  I rented it, for the lowest price, of course, just in case it wasn't worth the cash.  I really liked it.I do have my favorite episodes, though.  The first episode, "The Lost Boys" of the series and the first episode in Series 3.  Series 2 and 3 do not have specific episode titles, so I call this one, "Hearts"."The Lost Boys" introduces Detective Inspector Dave Creegan(Robson Green) to us.  Creegan is volitile, yet brilliant.  He had been wounded in the line of duty, which was followed by psychiatric counselling.  It makes one wonder why ACC Enwright(Michael Feast) called him back into service.  Creegan's emotional volitility caused the breakup of his marriage.After getting to know Creegan as a character, the audience can see why.  Creegan is a "driven" man and has instincts that can see through the mask of a criminal as he does in "The Lost Boys". Creegan sees through the mask of university professor Ronald Hinks(Ian McDiarmid-Sen. Palatine from Star Wars).  Creegan fights with Enwright and other team members to get Hinks arrested for kidnapping 3 boys, but Hink's lawyers have a larger case for Creegan's harrassment of Hinks.Creegan is teamed up with DI Susan Taylor(Nicola Walker), Detective Sargent Jonathan Kreitman(Adam Kotz) and Detective Constable Mark Rivers(Shaun Dingwall).  There is conflict almost immediately between the team members.I would like to see a 4th "Touching Evil" series, if only to clean up some questions before ending this intelligent series.  My biggest question, of course, is "Why did Enwright bring Creegan back in the first place?"  Creegan made it clear that he was a "one-to-one" person and that selling ice cream would probably be the best job he would enjoy AND he was psychologically unstable.  There is also the question of why Taylor was picked to partner with Creegan."Hearts" is just plain brilliant.  All the actors are at their best in this one, but Robson Green stands out.  After the murder of a friend, he finally crosses that psychological line.  Green is brilliant followed by Andy Serkis(Dr. Michael Lawler).  The other actors follow closely behind.Do I recommend this series.  YES, but only the British one.  When we Americans try to recreate a wonderful program like this, we always fall short.

reviewText: If it is possible to produce boring police/detective fiction about serial crime, then "Touching Evil" has managed to do that. Every episode begins with scenes that signal we are watching a story written in the police procedural genre, and just as consistently episodes end on the therapist's couch (metaphorically speaking). Throughout each episode, I found myself distracted enough to navigate away to email, Google, and breaking news sites, and to write this review. Thanks to the stop and play buttons.I have given up on "Touching Evil."  The story lines drag on, each scene in its turn characterized more by emotionality and less by strong plot and character development. Frame after frame is filled with smoggy visual effects, perhaps to signal engulfing, indefinable emotions. Characters spend endless moments discovering and sharing their deepest psychological states, detective to detective, and sometimes detectives with perpetrators.Perhaps this series tells the tale of a generational sea change in how to write, direct, produce and act in crime fiction.  Could it be that there is more audience and therefore more sponsor support for stories where audiences can feed on misery of characters and experience vicarious emotions rather than do the brainwork of following  a well-constructed plot, piecing together clues and motivations? At times scenes are simply weird and as such work better as scenes in psychological thrillers.Not to be a spoiler, I will not mention the episode: but there is one scene where the "strong" female presence on a crack investigative team is awakened in her bedroom, only to find the "killer" seated at the foot of her bed. She draws her gun but eventually loses her nerve. The two explore their emotions, and this is the 3rd time they do in the episode-- and they do it a few more times toward the end. All of this is set in pervasive and foggy lighting. The series begs for credulity, and so too it beggars any hope for authenticity, even authentic emotion."Touching Evil" is such a far cry from  Paul Abbott's earlier creative contributions to "Cracker." He wrote many of the episodes for "Cracker" and is the major story developer for "Touching Evil." Even the darkest crime fiction benefits from occasional foxhole humor, the kind of humor that gets police through the stress, in real life and on screen. "Touching Evil" is utterly without humor. Sadly the series departs from the hard-core "Cracker," its believability, its humor and its ability to engage and to never bore.

reviewText: This BBC produced police procedural is fantastic. The various crimes are gruesome and complicated to solve. Robson Green plays the most intense character I have ever seen him perform. All of the characters are well-developed and very well-acted. These comments also apply to the other seasons of this show. The quality of each episode never suffers. This series will be particularly enjoyed by those who like their characters imperfect, complicated, and dark.

reviewText: Fans of high-quality crime dramas set in Britian will find excellent writing and a talented cast in this gritty police drama. In "Touching Evil", Green plays DI Dave Creegan who is assigned to the OSC (Organized and Serial Crime unit). After surviving a gunshot wound to the head, Creegan discovers a unique ability to get into the criminal mind. Creegan is assisted by DI Susan Taylor (Nicola Walker) and several others.Season 1 contains three episodes:The Lost Boys - This episode introduces DI Dave Creegan of the newly-formed OSC (Organized and Serial Crime unit). The case investigated here concerns the abduction of three young boys. Creegan (Robson Green) and his partner DI Susan Taylor (Nicola Walker) are disconcerted to find a daffodil at the scene of the crime which reminds them of a case in Stuttgart several years earlier.In the second episode, the OSC investigates a series of strange homicides which are reminiscent of crimes committed across Europe. The link between the victims shows they knew each other back in Bosnia, when they worked for a relief agency. When a suspect turns up, Creegan and co. are befuddled as the man was presumed dead.The third episode deals with human mutilation and murder, and Creegan suspects copycat killings.I'd also recommend another British crime procedural series starring Robson Green as a clinical psychologist who delves into the psyche of killers:Wire in the Blood 4 Pack
